know_passage: Trade professions are necessary for society to function, require less than four years of training, and often pay above average wages. In contrast, the escalating cost of college makes traditional education less accessible. The overwhelming focus on the perceived value of a degree has exacerbated the ‘skills gap’ in the US, leading to a critical shortage of ‘middle-skill’ trade workers such as machinists, electricians, plumbers, and construction workers. One survey of US manufacturers found that 67% reported a “moderate to severe shortage of talent.” “Middle-skill” jobs represent half of all jobs in the US that pay middle-class wages. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, “middle-skill” jobs will make up 45% of projected job openings through 2014, but as of 2012 only 25% of the workforce had the skills to fill those jobs.
